repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Project to Support a Rural
            Economic Development Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Project to Support a
            Rural Economic Development Program Project for Guatemala
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: reducing political interference through
            transparent and competitive staff selection procedures and
            performance evaluations. Political instability and
            interference, with the resulting staff changes, affected
            project implementation. In anticipation of such challenges,
            it is critical to include mitigation measures, to the extent
            possible, during project preparation. In similar projects
            supported by the World Bank in Latin America, transparent
            and competitive staff selection procedures and performance
            evaluations are included in the agreements for project
            implementation. Measures that have proven highly successful
            in ensuring staff continuity include the use of two
            different external firms to take responsibility for: (i)
            staff recruitment, which encourages unaffiliated
            professionals to apply for project positions and widen the
            candidate pool, and (ii) yearly performance evaluations
            based on individual work plans and interviews with
            beneficiaries. Although the project achieved its objective
            in terms of reaching women, their active role in the Rural
            Producer Organization (RPOs) remains low. Specific
            strategies should be considered to foster women’s
            participation, such as establishing a specific business line
            to support the types of businesses opportunities that
            traditionally attract a high level of interest among women.
            On the other hand, implementing dissemination events
            specifically directed at women is a good practice in
            demand-driven interventions such as Rural Economic
            Development Program (PDER), as well as making targeted and
            customized gender sensitive training available for RPOs.

repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Project to Support the Rural
            Economic Development Program : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Project
            to Support the Rural Economic Development Program for
            Guatemala is to: (i) to improve the competitiveness of rural
            productive supply chains with strong indigenous
            participation; and (ii) to strengthen the institutional
            capacity of the public entities participating in the program
            for the adoption of a territorial management model with
            indigenous involvement. This restructuring will bring the
            following changes: (1) modification to the project's
            implementing arrangements; (2) extension of the project
            closing date to July 31, 2014 to allow for the new business
            plans to be implemented; (3) reallocation of loan proceeds;
            (4) modification to the project's disbursement
            arrangements; and (5) revision of indicator and targets.

repnme.cdata!:
Guatemala - Rural Economic Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Rural
            Economic Development Project for Guatemala is (i) to improve
            the competitiveness of rural productive supply chains with
            strong indigenous participation; and (ii) to strengthen the
            institutional capacity of the public entities participating
            in the program through the adoption of a territorial
            management model with indigenous participation. The purpose
            of this restructuring is to extend the closing date for the
            project, by 12 months - from February 1, 2013 until January
            31, 2014. The extension of closing date will be the third
            second level project restructuring and the first extension
            of closing date for this loan. Previous project
            restructurings were approved on April 7, 2009 and June 30,
            2011. Present disbursements amount to US$10,203,618.03 or
            34.01 percent of the total loan amount of US$30 million. The
            project's most recent progress towards achievement of
            PDO is rated unsatisfactory and implementation progress is
            moderately unsatisfactory. However, the project objectives
            continue to be achievable. Of the two PDO indicators, the
            one related to municipal projects stemming from the
            participatory process planning has already surpassed and
            doubled the target. The extension is necessary to allow the
            project to implement 27 already approved business plans, and
            seek the approval of more as feasible, enabling the project
            to reach the other PDO indicator (increase of total sales of
            the rural productive supply chain partnerships with US$50
            million during the project period). The project had a
            satisfactory audit report in 2011; the 2012 audit report
            will be financed by the Inter-American Development Bank
            (IADB) (a co-financier of the project). Financial
            management, procurement performance, and the overall
            safeguard compliance, continue to be moderately
            satisfactory. An action plan has been agreed with the client
            and officially sent to the World Bank on August 20, 2012.
            The action plan is formulated in 5 steps, the first being an
            extension of the closing date of the loan for 12 months. The
            remaining 4 steps of the action plan will be discussed in
            detail with the client during a mission in November 2012 and
            specific actions will be improving performance. This will
            involve a project restructuring related to improving
            implementing agency performance, reallocation of proceeds
            and adjustments of intermediate indicator targets.

display_title.display_title:
Guatemala - Rural Economic
            Development Project : restructuring : Main report
